awd_titl_txt: PIPP Phase I: Transdisciplinary Innovation in Predictive Science for Emerging Infectious Disease and Spillover
awd_abstract_narration:
The scale and impact of epidemics and pandemics are expected to increase substantively in future years given global trends in environmental change. Pandemics are most often caused by spillover events in which viruses from wild animals jump to people and spread, quickly outpacing containment efforts. Pandemics are best contained at the earliest stages of emergence, yet major hurdles have stood in the way of early detection of pandemic threats at the scale that is needed. We set forth an ambitious scientific agenda to overcome technological limitations impeding detection and characterization of emerging pandemic threats. Our team spanning engineering, computer science, social science, epidemiology, and virology with stakeholders from public health, wildlife health, and industry is first-of-a-kind to advance predictive intelligence for potential pandemics. We will develop new disease surveillance technologies that incorporate innovative sensing, epidemiological insights, and artificial intelligence strategies, to detect what animals are present and what viruses they carry - all remotely with little human intervention. We seek to develop diverse, inclusive, and highly functional transdisciplinary research teams and trainees, to move beyond the state of the art in predictive intelligence for pandemics to inform national and global health security. 

We address the grand challenge of generating actionable intelligence for early detection of pandemic threats at the point of disease spillover from animals to people. We are planning a transdisciplinary center and associated research to advance our ability to characterize environmental change and animal-human interactions that facilitate the emergence of pandemic threats, and develop predictive capabilities in forecasting pandemic risk, to enable an evidence-base that can inform pandemic prevention. Research advances will be focused on 1) characterizing environmental conditions and the human dimensions of disease emergence, especially the animal and human movements, networks, and social systems that facilitate spillover at the animal-human interface, 2) inventing broad-spectrum sensor technologies for rapid, accurate, safe, and scalable pathogen detection tailored to a range of animals in diverse environments, and 3) improving forecasting by integration of epidemiologic and landscape data with machine learning to advance predictive intelligence. Our team will foster the convergence of creative ideas, novel approaches and technologies, transdisciplinary collaboration and communication, participatory community science, and cross-training for innovation for a profoundly diverse workforce.

This award is supported by the cross-directorate Predictive Intelligence for Pandemic Prevention Phase I (PIPP) program, which is jointly funded by the Directorates for Biological Sciences (BIO); Computer, Information Science and Engineering (CISE); Engineering (ENG) and Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences (SBE).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The University of California, Davis, University of Southern California, University of California, Los Angeles, and Northeastern University formed a consortium to work together towards transdisciplinary innovation in predictive science for pandemics under NSF's Predictive Intelligence for Pandemic Prevention (PIPP) Phase I Program. Our Phase I award was a planning grant to develop ideas for transformative research urgently needed to address grand challenges in prevention of pandemics. Our efforts focused on defining center-scale research priorities while enabling transdisciplinary collaboration, communication, and cross-training for innovation focused on several collaborative pilot projects. Together, our team identified the most fundamental gaps in our knowledge of the mechanisms involved in spillover of pandemic threats from animals to humans, as well as the theoretical and technical challenges that limit our progress in these investigations. These challenges were translated into research priorities focused on 1) characterization of the wildlife and human dimensions facilitating spillover at the animal-human interface, 2) development of sensor technologies for rapid detection of disease events, tailored to animals and humans in diverse environments, and 3) integration of data and modeling to advance predictive insights into pandemics.

Our team developed approaches to team science in a multi-disciplinary environment, implemented pilot projects as proof of concept for cross-disciplinary collaboration, and planned strategic directions and next steps for our future research. In doing so, we sought collaborative engagement with a range of groups interested in pandemic research and integrated this highly diverse expertise into research activities. From the outset, our team recognized the need for real world input and an iterative process in the development of innovative technologies, with engagement of a broad range of stakeholders and potential end users in the application of technologies and evolution of knowledge. Thus cross-sectoral knowledge sharing was integral to our goals and was achieved through engagement of diverse institutions, organizations, and agencies in workshops and meetings in our Phase I activities. To this end, our team hosted four highly integrated transdisciplinary workshops which included participants across engineering, computer science, virology, wildlife health, public health, conservation, and epidemiology. The aim of these engagements was to prioritize gaps that must be addressed for pandemic prevention and inform on the direction of our research. Workshops and meetings were convened around the co-development of center goals, strategies, and how best to link, integrate, and prioritize research and technology development based on the most pressing needs identified. To streamline our communication strategies across disciplines for these workshops, our team co-designed presentations to broaden and increase awareness of disciplinary expertise and terminology, identify synergistic needs, and share research progress. In addition to sharing knowledge with the broader scientific community, stakeholders, and the public through the development of reports and presentations, our work was also highlighted in media communications focused on the environment and health.

Engaging students and trainees in transdisciplinary research opportunities and promoting a diverse workforce was a key outcome of Phase I activities. To this end, we engaged 24 undergraduate students, 15 graduate students, and 5 postdoctoral scholars across our institutions, providing significant opportunities for training and professional development. Students and trainees participated in team meetings, workshops, and engaged in pilot research activities.

Pilot activities undertaken as part of this award were designed to inform on the feasibility of proposed research activities and expand our research agenda for the next phase of transdisciplinary research. Our team outlined plans and tested approaches for sensing and classifying wild animal populations using thermal and auditory data collected in a range of habitats and settings. Additionally, we deployed and optimized prototype sensors for detection of aerosolized pathogens and host signals, piloting these sensors in controlled settings. We also tested new approaches to detection of antibodies in non-invasively collected samples. We also integrated data across multiple research foci to inform on the design of algorithms and predictive models, enhancing our team's capacity for future transdisciplinary activities.

Finally, our Phase I efforts and activities allowed us to develop a unique center-scale plan with a collaborative and highly transdisciplinary research team. We were able to build off our successes as a Phase I team to develop a Phase II plan that identifies the most pressing needs to advance the state of the art for research into the pre-emergence of pandemic threats to inform risk mitigation and preparedness.
